author: potluck

description.text:
Premise: this is just a remix of an existing design.

I do not take any credit for it. I simply collected the various parts in a single stl, trying to optimize the distribution. If you want different hands, look at the one i used as base.

All the pieces needed to make the robot, minus the sword, grouped into one single stl, with approximately 15x15 cm footprint. Both hands are fists with hole.

The pieces are arranged in such a way that the tallest are located near he center of the group (and plate), where the errors on the Z axis should be minimal.
The distribution should also maximize extruding vs travelling movements of the head.

The 1.1 version fixes the leg insert: there was only one and was not horizontal. The file is also significantly smaller, as side effect of exporting it with Blender, instead of Cura.

Hollow jack-o-lantern with a removable cap.

Modified 10/15/2017: Added a base to fit over a small LED tea light. The tea light diameter is 37 mm. The picture reflects a print at 300 Microns.

description.text:
The device causes a 3D printer to "Pause" when filament goes missing or becomes tangled on the spool. After correcting the problem, a user can "Resume" the printing to complete the job. To eliminate failed prints, a Micro Switch connects to OctoPrint running on a Raspberry Pi. Simple code gracefully pauses the printer and then resumes when the problem is corrected.

Designed by Melvin Cruz, Jon Schull and Skip Meetze at Rochester e-NABLE Lab, the Filament FAULT Detector builds on https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2095911 by brotherchris.

Use up all of your nearly empty spools!
The device allows you to use the filament to the end of the spool, the it pauses for you to add another spool then continue printing the job.

Tangled filament still causes failed prints for many makers!
The device pauses the printer if the filament is tangled on the spool, and it lets you untangle the filament then resume printing the job.

For detailed instructions see
http://e-nable.org/2017/10/17/do-your-prints-fail-because-filament-gets-tangled-or-because-filament-runs-out/

title: Printable Clothes Line / General Object Hanger

description.text:
Well, it is kinda of windy where I live and I have blankets that need to be air dried. I wanted a setup that would be easy to setup, take down, and wouldn't take much space. So, I designed a fully printable clothes line. The bodies/anchors are printed and the line is 3mm filament. 
You can also use it to hang other objects up to such as plants, etc... or hang stuff on columns easy where access is harder. I will also be using it to hang outdoor Christmas lights, between columns, this year over a large spans that the lights themselves could not span without sagging horribly.  
Yes, I could have used rope with some knots. However, it would have not have been so easy to remove.... and not nearly as fun to do.

1) Download the body and the key. 2) Print two of each. 3) Clean them up and maybe drill the holes out slightly(depending on your settings). 4) Get some 3mm filament(I used some scrap I had around). 5) Insert the key into the body. 6) Run your 3mm filament into the front of the hole that does not have the key next to it and pull a about 12" through(this depends on your application). 7) Run the filament through the hole on the backside of the body until a couple of inches are pulled through. 8) Go to the object you wish to hang on and pull the keyside filament tight, thus wrapping the filament around the object. Trim the filament if needed. 9) You can deform the filament with a 90 degree bend to hold it if the loads are not going to be high. However, if loads are high I suggest folding the plastic over and using some acetone to "melt" the end of the filament together creating a surface that can not be pulled through the key side hole. 10) Repeat steps 5-9 for the other side of the filament. Tips:
1) Look at the pictures.
2) Removing the key allows for the setup to be rapidly removed.
3) This can be used for more than just a clothes line. Use your imagination.
4) The filament will eventually creep if it is constant stress. How, much depends on your application. Yes, I could have used rope with some knots. However, it would have not have been so easy to remove.... and not nearly as fun to do.

author: jbwatts

description.text:
Topeak brand bike racks have a bracket on the back end which you can fix a light onto, but only certain lights fit. My tail light had the common design of being intended for wrapping around the seat post, with a rubber clamp. So I made this adapter which is the same diameter as most common seat posts, to give the light something to grab on to.

I used 1/2" long 10-24 bolts to attach it, and M5 should work as well. Although you don't necessarily need the bolts; the wraparound light will hold it in place, but of course if you remove the light then it will fall off! So bolt it on, kids.

Printer Brand:

Prusa

Printer:

Prusa Mk2

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

1.5

This is my very first from-scratch design using TinkerCAD. I needed a simple cup pull (such as those used on drawers) but couldn't find anything to download that would meet my needs. I'm actually going to use two of these as grab handles mounted to either side of bottom of my Plexiglass printer enclosure in order to make it easier to lift on and off of the platform. I'm amazed at how strong this handle is even in PLA at 15% infill. I would have used a lot less infill but it didn't seem to drop the print time by much in Cura.

This handle is about 150mm long by 30mm high by 30mm deep. There's a thick handhold to assist in holding on to the bottom edge. I printed it hole-side down (for the sake of better threads) without supports, and the handhold sags a bit but still works fine for my needs. You may want to use supports or flip the model so that the handhold is on the printbed if you want a better handhold.

The mounting holes are supposed to be for 4mm x 8mm metric screws. I don't have any 4mm screws to test with so I'm not sure how well they work yet. The mounting bosses are actually about 8mm in diameter by 11mm deep to allow some leeway in case the holes need to be enlarged slightly. If I find that people would like to use the design but need to change up the holes, I'll see about making the CAD file available.

Printer:

Creality CR-10

No

Doesn't Matter

15% or less

author: robguiri

description.text: A 1 kilometer token to celebrate a distance related accomplishment. In this case, I was celebrating 1 kilometer of printed filament.

print_settings.Notes:: Use a brim or a raft, whichever you prefer.

description.text:
Description:

Lead solder produces harmful fumes. Lead-Free solder contains a core that produces arguably more harmful fumes. Choose your poison.

How about less poison?

There are other Solder Fume Extractors out there, but I wanted something minimalistic. This extractor stands up stable, covers the soldering area, stands on any side, and prints easily. I printed the fan cover in about 1.2hrs, the back plate in about 1.4 hours, and the front box in about 2.1 hours. I printed this at 0.3 resolution, 60% infill, and 60 mm/s speed.

Zeebly's design works with a helping hands. I was not able to get this to work with the helping hands that I have, so I re-designed this. I wanted something simple that is easily printed (I believe in KISS, keep it simple stupid. It's my mantra). So, I added a flat back cover that allows the fan to sit level. I re-designed the box area so that things overlapped to form a square. I removed the helping hands attachment. Now, the unit can sit flat on any surface thus removing the need for anything extra.

Parts:

1x 120mm Computer Fan (I used a CoolMaster 12VDC, 0.16A case fan)
1x AC to 12VDC Wall Wart Adapter (must supply > .2A for my fan choice)
Tools and parts to connect fan to AC Adapter
4x #6 bolt 2.5 Inches long (M4 65mm SHOULD work)
8x #6 nut (M4 nut)
2x #6 nut (M4 nut) OPTIONAL
12x #6 washer (M4 washer)
2x Activated Carbon Filter (I used Corner Biz Aquarium filters from Amazon, 1 package)
https://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B06XSH898Q/ref=oh_aui_search_detailpage?ie=UTF8&psc=1

Instructions (see pictures):

  1. Print one each of the STL files (fan cover flat, back plate with one wall, front plate with three walls).
  2. Take each of the four bolts and put a washer on it.
  3. Take the fan cover, choose the best side, and slide the bolts in so the best side faces towards the bolt head. Orienting the screws in this way allows for easy filter replacement without taking apart the entire unit.
  4. Figure out the fan orientation. The front-back arrow on the fan should point towards the fan cover (see IMPORTANT image). This is IMPORTANT! It is important the extractor pulls fumes away. Blowing air towards the soldering area increase splash danger. Also, it cools the solding area, and it blows the fumes directly at you.
  5. Slide the fan onto the bolts using the orientation from above.
  6. Slide the back plate over the fan with the one wall facing away from the fan. It doesn't matter which side the wall faces as the unit can rest on any side when completed.
  7. Slide a washer onto each bolt, and then a nut. Tighten this down now. This keeps the unit from falling apart when replacing the filter, and keeps the fan tight against the chassis.
  8. (OPTIONAL) Screw a nut down the two bolts next to the one wall until the top of the nut is level with the top of the one wall. This prevents over-tightening of the front plate in the final step.
  9. The two foam filters do not need their sides trimmed - they will squish in. I did find it easier to take off about 0.5 inches (12mm) from the point of each corner (thus cutting off a triangle). This allows the filters to slide past the screws easier. If you're a squisher, you can try squishing. Once a squisher, always a squisher, and nothing wrong with that!
  10. Go ahead and squish the filters into the front plate.
  11. Now squish the front plate onto the back plate with the filters facing towards the fan AND the missing wall on the front plate oriented toward the one wall on the back plate. Squish and jiggle around to line up the screws. This sounds complicated, but it's much easier in practice.
  12. Slide a washer onto each bolt.
  13. IMPORTANT! Do NOT over-tighten (OPTIONAL helps with this)! Add and tighten a nut to each bolt, carefully.

Printing:

I printed each part with a brim. A raft would also work, but I decided to use a brim. Good old brim, nothing beats that. Except a raft.

Thanks:

Thanks to Zeebly for the design!

Printer:

Anet A8

Resolution:

0.3

Infill:

60

Notes:

Use a brim or a raft, whichever you prefer.

title: Mixed Filament runout and guide -  Anet A8

description.text:
Very simple filament runout switch (1.75mm filament, mechanical endstop with roller arm) with filament guide. I mixed two other designs ( sb43201 and jrwells) ; https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2577717 and https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1795148.

I wanted a position close enough to the extruder, firmly fixed and no screws for the mechanical endstop. The chosen solution is to use the initial place of my filament guide (https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1795148).

Two parts to print : runout_filament_with_guide and endstop_blocker.

I tested on a Ramps board with the OctoPrint plugin "Filament Sensor Reloaded" (http://plugins.octoprint.org/plugins/filament_sensor_reloaded/): it works very well. Not yet implemented on my Anet A8.

The mechanical endstop used (with roller arm) : https://fr.aliexpress.com/item/50pcs-lot-New-3D-printer-accessories-Makerbot-MK7-MK8-Micro-Roller-Lever-Arm-Normally-Open-Close/32681500791.html

The original screws can be used as for " Anet A8 filament guide" (https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1795148)

I added two diagrams showing both positions (with and without filament), and also F3D files (to change the design, if you have other endstop sensors).

Anet A8

description.text:
I designed this part because I want an adjustable Z-Axis endstop that was simple to mount, easy to print, that doesn’t require modifications on the printer like drill new holes and it should be hidden from the front.

You will need a long M3 screw (I use a 30mm M3 screw), and two small screws to attach to Anet A8 X axis left plastic mount bracket (I used two M3 x 5mm screws)

I advise using an M3 tap on the support - but please don't tap all to the end, leave some plastic/material to increase the thread friction (like a locknut). You can print a knob for the screw to adjust it manually without a screwdriver.

Printer:

Anet A8

Rafts:

No

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

0.2

Infill:

25-35%

Notes:

Be sure to have a strong bed adhesion, I advise using brim.

description.text:
I designed this from scratch in Fusion360 but I got the idea and mounting style from gpvirzi's mount that mounts on 1 bed screw and is mounted in the corner of the bed. I prefer to have my time lapses in the middle of the bed which is why I made this. It connects to both of the front bed leveling screws to make it rock solid. When printing fast there is hardly any wobble in the camera.

This is for the original 300x300 CR-10.

The model should be printed how it is imported into your slicer. I used support when I printed it but with 3 walls you probably don't need it.

https://youtu.be/GnSBs_3Zhc0

title: Anet A8 X-Tensioner for protruding bars

description.text:
Hi all

The two x-axis bars of my Anet A8 protrude on the left.
I created a x-tensioner for this special set up.
The tension force is directly applied to both bars so any bent is minimized.
Just print two sleeves ("casquillo_8mm.stl" file) and one x-tensioner ("X-Tensioner2.stl" file)
You will need two M8 nuts and screws. You will also probably need a longer belt.
You can use the original M3 nut, screw and pulley.
Insert a sleeve in each protruded bar.
Insert the M8 nuts in the x-tensioner.
Mount the pulley into the x-tensioner with the belt already rolled up.
Insert the M8 screws and that's all.
I may suggest you to also print a couple of M8 knobs to handle them easier.

Printer:

Anet A8

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

Doesn't Matter

Resolution:

0.2

Infill:

100%

Notes:

Maybe you don't need 100% infill but I did it just in case.

author: jjvelar

description.text: Craftsman hex driver tool holder.

I printed my tool holder with the over-center snaps flat down on the plate. I also printed in ABS at about 40% infill for good flexibility.  
The holder can be mounted with screws at the top or underneath. I preferred the screws underneath in the end.

comments.text: Update: I had one of the clips break on me yesterday. I removed the holder from my workbench to inspect it and found some other clips that were cracked. I've printed a couple new holders. My settings this time around were 60% infill, .2mm layer height, and 4 perimeter shells. That nearly made the fingers solid. This is much stronger and it's what I recommend to others printing it for the first time. I use my hex drivers quite often so they get snapped into the holder many times. Hopefully these new prints will last longer.
comments.author: heathenx

author: jovanessian

description.text:
The Zigview Waist-Level-Finder is a gadget containing a small digital camera and an LCD panel. It looks through your eyepiece for you and displays what it sees so you can take properly framed photos holding your camera at waist height, or if you swivel it around, holding the camera above your head.

It's great for film SLRs because it just looks through the optical viewfinder and displays what it sees.

Unfortunately, the part holding the brand-specific eyepiece clip to the device is week and broke on mine very quickly. Zigview don't make this part any more, so I did.

Printer:

Anet A8

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

No

Infill:

20%

Finishing

Printing in PLA, the part is too brittle to allow the adaptor to be clipped on without breaking. I tried inserting a pause at Z=4mm using my slicer, but the printer just ignored it.

In the end I achieved a satisfactory result by heating the flanges using the hot air gun on my rework station set to a medium-low airflow at 120°C. After installing the eyepiece clip, I gently reformed the flanges before the PLA set.

If you don't have a rework station, you might try boiling water.

author: nyyanks

title: Silencer \ suppressor \ moderator (lead dust collector) for airgun.
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
I do not take any responsibility and I´m not liable for any damage caused through use of this product. Always be careful and use required safety equipment.
Update 24/10/17: Version for 1 inch pvc pipe

This is a modular silencer (or lead dust collector) designed for a 5.5mm (.22cal) pcp air rifle. Could be usable for 6.35mm (.25cal ) as there should be enough clearance for the pellet but I have not tested it for this caliber. Right now it is threaded for 1/2 UNF x 20 as it is widely used. If needed I can model and upload other thread sizes quite easily. Just post in comments.

All pieces are 36mm (inner) /40mm (outer) in diameter. Baffles are 20mm in length, threaded barrel cap takes 15mm and the end cap takes 10mm of room in length. Use 36mm (inner D) / 40mm (outer D) pipe for the body.

In the photos I´ve printed 10 pieces of baffles (PETG) so the length for the body (pipe) would be: 10x20mm + 15mm +10mm = 225mm. I´m using pvc pipe for the outerior for it is cheap, light and easily available in hardware stores.

I suggest using epoxy or strong glue for the threaded barrel cap and using 2-3 scrub crews (you need to make a hole and thread them) for the end cap. This way you can remove one of the caps and service the inner pieces if needed.

I used PLA on my first version (painted it black) and I´ve shot over 500 shots with it, still working well and in one piece. My rifle is regulated and modified Hatsan AT44 with 25 foot-pounds of energy (15.89gr going 850fps).

I SUGGEST using ABS or PET(G) if you can for more strength. Pieces in photos are printed in transparent PETG.

Is it any good?
This is hands down the best silencer I´ve ever used on my rifle (used 8 baffles).

comments.text:

I wonder if repeatedly unscrewing the silencer will not damage the plastic thread with the steel thread of the barrel?

remixed_from.author: Tech2C
remixed_from.title: E3Dv6 Bowden X-carriage mount v2 for Prusa i3

title: i3 Dual E3D V6 X Carriage

description.text: A remix of the E3D X Carriage for dual extrusion.

Printer Brand:

Prusa

Printer:

Prusa Clone

Rafts:

No

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

0.40mm

Infill:

30%

Notes:

I've printed and used this design in PLA and PETG. It was easier to control the nozzle height with PLA, but PETG may stand up to the heat better than PLA. I don't use ABS.

Take your time mounting and aligning the two hotends!

This is NOT a silver bullet design which will give you amazing aligned nozzles without any effort. You'll have to tune both nozzle position and general print settings, including firmware settings, to get the best out of this design. You will need 2 blower fans. Believe me, in this configuration 2 are better than one. Note also that I use a microswitch mounted on the upper-left arm for X axis homing. Your requirements may vary. I use 2 genuine E3D v6 hotends in Bowden configuration with 0.4mm nozzles. I've NOT tried this design with clones, since I've found them to be so variable in physical dimensions. Not only are genuine E3D parts more reliable and better value than clones, they've made some great contributions to 3D printing and for my money they deserve support.

The basic assembly instructions are more or less the same as for the original thing (https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1632847) with the following additions:

Your hotends will need to be mirrored with regard to the side from which the heater cart and thermistor wires enter the heat brick, so that they both fit with sufficient clearance from the cooling ducts. See the photos if you're not sure what I mean.

Keep the left hand and center bracket screws slightly lose, perform a Z home and adjust the height of the left hotend while doing the "paper sheet" leveling method. It will help if a) your bed is level and b) your X rails are as close to horizontal as possible. When you're happy that the friction on the paper is as close to identical as you can get it, slowly tighten the bracket while continuing to adjust the left hotend to maintain level. Once the bracket is nice and tight, insert the holding M4 screw, the hole for which you should have tapped for an M4 screw.

Set the hotend offset as X:26mm Y:0mm, select a good dual extrusion calibration model and adjust the offsets until you're happy with the alignment.

NOTE that you WILL lose some print area in the Y axis. The probe offsets are around X:12mm Y:-29mm and obviously your Z offset will depend on your own positioning.

Adding dual extrusion is a technical challenge, which puts great emphasis on avoiding zitting and heavy stringing on the print surface - lumps WILL cause problems with the final print so make SURE you have your extrusion rate, retraction settings and tool change settings as good as you can get them. This is NOT an optional step and will most likely take longer than any other step. While I'll try to offer assistance, I can't promise I'll be able to solve all the problems people encounter. In particular, firmware changes and how to use dual extrusion generally and host configuration in particular are topics perhaps better addressed with research by the user.

Basically I cloned and aligned two of the stanard thing plates and brackets from https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1632847, added screw and nut holes for the i3 rework X carriage, and altered the left hand hotend holder to allow height adjustment. All this was done in TinkerCad.

First calibration prints will come after making sure your nozzles are level in Z. You'll also want to tune in your extrusion rates so they're balanced. This image shows an example first print, which needs extruder 1 (white) to be turned UP a little, and firmware offsets corrected.

Calibration will take time and filament!

Firstly, use whichever filament you have the most success with for the calibration process. There's nothing worse than making a hard process harder.

For your first prints following a basic alignment as described above, print single material models. If one or other hotend is lower than the other, this is where you'll find out. Make absolutely 100% sure that neither nozzle impinges on a print when it's idle. Once you've got single material prints working, move on to printing your calibration model. I use https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:533814 because it's a quick print and makes it nice and clear what you need to do. I also use https://s3.amazonaws.com/cdn.freshdesk.com/data/helpdesk/attachments/production/1033413213/original/offset%20guide%20image.jpg?1446455113 as a handy guide to what numbers need to change.

Take your time and get this step right. You might notice at this point that one of your extruders runs leaner than the other - take care of that as soon as you can. You know what a well extruded print looks like, and both your extruders need to be spot on for good dual material prints.

When you have the calibration print looking like all the squares are aligned as in the model, it's time to try something more complex - I quite like these little cones https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:21773 because they scale well and they're also useful for dialing in part cooling. Airflow will be different around the new carriage and your settings may need to change. For PLA I blip the fan to 75% on layer 2 and 100% on layer 4 but your settings may well vary. Use the cone prints to dial in the final tiny tweaks to the offset - run your nail up and down the model and you'll feel any offset errors.

Finally, remember to recheck your calibration before any production or long prints, especially if something happens to jar the carriage. If you find yourself having to do a cold pull on one of the hotends, you most likely will need to recalibrate again, particularly in Z. Make calibration part of your regular maintenance.

author: DrMistry

description.text:
The PinBox 3000 is a table-top pinball machine that comes as flat pieces of cardboard and transforms into a fully-functional game in an hour. I designed these pieces to be glued-on elements on cardboard blanks that you can inter-change.

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=wuVhQMGgAEA&t=3s

All can be printed as-in, except Marble Man, which needs support. One of my printers just supported the ears and nose, and the print was great. The other added support to the tunnel, which seemed unnecessary.

Some prints may need Exacto knife cleanup.

comments.text:
I knew I'd find something for pinbox. I'm actually hoping to design some stuff for my (3rd grade) son's. It seems so counter to the papercraftiness of the project, but the combination seems incredible, especially if I want to incorporate some traditional pinball elements.My intent is to actually create spoked pins on the bottom to poke through the surface to hold it in place and allow for replacement/changes.
I hope this can get him interested in doing some 3D design/printing of his own.
I hope this went well with your classes. I teach HS math and haven't the foggiest idea how I could integrate these types of projects into curriculum. they seem to apathetic unless they are already doing it on their own or in art class.
Good on you!!
comments.author: iamchrismoran

comments.text: Hi again. Here's a couple of shots of what my second graders made: https://twitter.com/morrill_rob/status/955581925552353280 . I cut out large pieces of card stock for each kid, and that let them glue and draw on their play surface, and they were easily interchanged on the Pinboxes. The 3d printed spinners worked well. I highly recommend this Pinbox video on game theory: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=iKZKJ1igLg8 . The elements they use could be either 3d printed or cut from cardboard and glued to the card stock pieces. I'm noodling on math connections for hs kids, but no epiphanies yet.

title: Zonestar Print Head 45mm Bushing Holder Mod LM8LUU

description.text: I wanted to improve my print quality on my Zonestar P802QR2 because the head has to much X & Y and Z free movement; so, I replaced the 24mm bushings with 45mm bushings (LM8LUU) on the back of the print head (X axis). I created this holder to mount under the Zonestar bushing mounts. I removed the old bushing by removing the C ring clips and slid the 45 in its place. The holder mounts keep the bushings in place (no play). You have to print 2, 1 for each bushing; but, you can add just one LM8LUU bushing to the top bushing to better stabilize the print head. The second is a spacer or a holder for the lower bushing. For the bottom bushing, clip the high sides corners and use it just as a 2mm spacer . You are required to clip the bottom bushing holder corners so it will fit. You can do that in your CAD app, Slicer, or ,like me, wire cutters) to clip the sides or corners, The two photos show the improvements produced by changing both LM8LUU's bushings on this printer (changing the bottom bushing improves vertical print-head lift as well). Print setting were the same.

FLSun Cube and Q802 QR2

description.text:
These feet are simple 3D printer feet. They were specifically designed for the Flyingbear P905, but they may be compatible with many other printers. FB_Feet_Part1 is the top, and FB_Feet_Part2 is the bottom. The bottom was designed to be printer in flexible, to absorb some vibrations (depending on how much infill you have), and to prevent the printer from scraping the desk it is sitting on, when it is moved around. The top part is designed to distribute the weight of the printer evenly on the flexible part. They fit great on my printer, but you might need to scale them if you are putting them on a different type of printer.

https://youtu.be/tOu-bZgyxv0

title: Balisong / butterfly knife - weighted and very nice

description.text:
This is a very nice and smooth balisong, use M4 screws all around. Be sure to use locking nuts.

At the bottom of each handle, use a screw, 2 normal nuts and finish it off with a locking nut (one nut goes in the handle, that's why the M4 nut shape is there). The handles will be nice and weighted.

This version has a printed center pin on the blade! It will react like a real balisong :)

I print the handles FLAT on the bed with the holes up. And between the handle I use support. I do this so the holes will be nice and smooth (I don't care about the inside being supersmooth you don't see that).

I printed at .2mm layer height, 60% infill to make it nice and strong!

Check it out: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=FOcKPevliAE

title: Universal (sort of ) 5 colour Diamond Hot End Mount

description.text: This is a (sort of) universal mount for the 5 colour Diamond Hot End in OpenScad. It consists of just the parts needed to take the 5 colour hot end and 50mm fan. It isn't a customiser as such but you should add whatever boss or bracket is needed to suit your particular machine. I've included the OpenScad file which I have annotated so you should be able to work out how it works and where you need to add your own mounting arrangement. I'm no expert in OpenScad so the coding may not look pretty but it gets the job done. Feel free to modify it any way you like (just give me credit for the original).

title: Roche Easyfill Insulin Cartridge for Spirit Insulin Pump

description.text:
This simple design is to hold filled 3.15ml Easyfill cartridges in your fridge ready for use when the current one runs out or needs changing. These cartridges are used by the Roche Diagnostics Spirit Combo insulin pump.

There are 3 holes for the cartridges (as many as a 10ml bottle of insulin allows). This is a handy means for preparing the cartridges, as it can be used to eliminate the air bubbles at the top and means you can get going quicker without quite so much priming.

Actually the mk8 now

I created the first of these out of styrene sheets, glued together. This lasted for years but out of alignment and was easily knocked over due to it's lightness.
My first 3d printer design didn't make it to the plastic. The second I actually printed and learned lots by doing so. Mostly to do with shrinkage of PLA.
Being new to the 3D printing world, I used the easiest program I could find that allowed me to set the object sizes specifically. It's crude but workable.
Of course the next day, I was playing with the model in Slic3r and discovered that one of the holes for cartridges had gone walkabouts. So I've created a new model.

title: 38mm (1.5in) Recessed Basing for Miniature Figures
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text: I was looking for recessed basing for my newly minted and acquired 10mm WW2 Pendraken miniatures and came across OntologicalShock's beautifully crafted Figure Squad Basing https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2071698, which I modded by adding a flat round disk converted from a flattend Rostock Calibration Cylinder https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:139113. These are sized to 38mm (1.5in) and 4mm tall with a 2mm recess, which apparently is the standard for metal cast figures at many scales. The built-in pips are the sweet gravy on top, so now I can colour code for different units and sections. Kit-bashed in Simplify3D. Printed using PLA from Materio3D.com

title: Champion's league cup - text ans symbol

description.text:
This is additions of UEFA symbol and text on the cup, design for attaching on this model https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:319038

It is design for a trophy of about 23 cm overall height - that's the original cup in the link above, uniformly scaled X675 (you donr need to scale the symbol and text only the cup).

I looked for a cup model for a friend and the one including the engraving did not turned out so good so i just design this thinning printing it alone would yield better results (and it did)

Instruction:
Print it in the lowest res possible (above 0.1mm it will have a significant detail loss) .
Print it laying flat (rotate 90 or -90 deg from original position)
Print it slowly - i used 15 mm/s profile on cura

when attaching to the cup, i used UHU all plastic adhesive, that allows several seconds of adjusting before it is fixed.
the letters is more tricky. first draw a line (i used long piece of tape) to mark a straight row, than glued each letter by hand. Here also i tried UHU al plastic but it was very difficult as the glue is very viscose ans can be applied on such a small surface with out residues, so i when to Gorilla supper glue, that still have about 10 seconds for alignment.

The apostrophe above the E in "Europeens" i tried to do the same but it was too small to print ok, so i just designed a 0.8X0.8X6 mm box, printed it and cut it to the desired size.

Im attaching the fusion 360 file for the text, you can just edit the sketch there to whatever font and style you want (what i used looked to me closest to the original)

ENJOY

title: AM8 MGN12 z-axis / extended x-axis 300 buildplate

description.text:
Modified AM8 and AM8 2020 x-axis parts. 400mm MGN12 rails used for z-axis. Relocated z-motor position for extended travel of the x-axis. Not entirely sure if a 300x300 bed will fit due to actual bed size measuring 310mm but a 300mm glass will definitely fit. Removal of 2040 z-axis supports may be necessary.

Included both normal size x mounts and anti backlash size mounts. Print the x-axis with supports on.

1 side of parts is included. Just mirror the part in your slicer for opposite side.

Edit: NOV 5 2017

Re-worked the design of the XZ mounts. Found once mounted they were not strong enough. Had some flexing in the z direction. New ones don't flex at all. I suggest printing these XZ mounts with 100% infill.

Notes:

Can be printed without support structure if you have an extruder fan that cools the print.

This was designed to be as minimal as possible. To support the echo dot against the wall without getting in its way at all.
The tiny teeth securing the echo dot will not get in the way of the 7 mic array. The open back allows the downward firing speaker to resonate sound through the wall instead of the table surface.
The cable opening allows the echo to be oriented either left or right and perfectly frames the Amazon logo.

Final Design

Download preconfigured Frimware
Download only the config file

Bed Position Troubleshot

When i have downloaded the frimware, my home position (0,0) was alwais out of the bed. Maybe i have a different endstop or it's the carriage's fault. Anyway, the settings was wrong.

the original configuration values:

X_MIN_POS: -36
Y_MIN_POS: -8

when i move the hotend to the true bed home, i get this position on the LCD :
X: -17 y:20

I then realise the _MIN_POS varriable define the endstop position.

new frimware values:
X_MIN_POS: -19 (36 - 17)
Y_MIN_POS: -28 (-8 - 20)

hope this help someone :)

Sensor calibration screw

I have found than the sensor need to be adjusted by a screwdriver or an alenkey. Check this video before doing offset calibration.

Really nice tool to calibrate the offset (In beta) Sensor Calibration

Before doing calibration, please reset the offset to 0 with M851 Z0 or clear the EMPROM with the M502 command.

If you follow the video instruction, please type the M211 S0 command before, this will allow you to go under the 0. The offset you should get will be around -1mm. Mine was -1.15.

Extruder calibration

If you change firmware, test the extruder calibration before any print. You will 99% sure need to change the steps/mm. Check this tutorial to learn how to do it.

Base Documentation (Where i started from)

The original frimware was given to me by Rob Hart

Many help found on the Fb Group Official, Anet, A8R 3D printer Support Group (Inc RepRap Prusa i3 clones)

Sensor: 3D Touch (a clone)

Extruder: Geekcreit (E3DV6 clone) Long 1.75mm

Motor Mount: Remote Extruder Kit

Simplify3D Startup Script

Trying to remove the need of manipulations, this is my startup script.

G21 ;metric values 
G90 ;absolute positioning 
M82 ;set extruder to absolute mode 

M107 ;start with the fan off 
M106 S0 ;start with the fan off 

G28 X0 Y0 ;move X/Y to min endstops 
;G28 Z0 ;move Z to min endstops 

M140 S[bed0_temperature]
M190 S[bed0_temperature]  ; Set bed temp and wait to be reached
M104 S150 T0; Set extruder #0 and do not wait - preheat
M109 S150 T0; Set extruder #0 and wait

M280 P0 S160 ; Reset 3D-Touch
G4 P500
M280 P0 S10 ; Pin out
G4 P500
M280 P0 S90 ; Pin back
G4 P500

G28
M104 S[extruder0_temperature] T0; Set extruder #0 and dont wait

M117 Auto Leveling ...
G29
G0 X10 Y10 Z20 F1300
G0 X10 Y10 Z0 ;Move Extruder to check the bed level
G4 P15000 ;whait 15 seconds

G0 X0 Y0 Z20 F800 ;Move Extruder
M109 S[extruder0_temperature] T0 ;Set extruder #0 and wait

G1 Z15.0 F300 ;move the platform down to 15mm 
G1 F800 ;set traveling Speed

;Move to the 0,0 position (in my bed, it's on the very border, filament go off the bed)
G0 X0 Y0 Z2 ; try X-0.2 Y-0.2 if your bed is to flush

G1 Z0.0 F300 ;move the platform down 0mm 

G92 E0                  ;zero the extruded length
G1 F200 E25              ;extrude 2.5mm of feed stock
G92 E0                  ;zero the extruded length again

G1 Z1.0  E-2  F1800 ;lift the extruder and retract filament
G0 Z5.0 X5 Y20 E-0.5 F1800 ;move up and retract filament while moving
G92 E0                  ;zero the extruded length again

;G1 F[travel_speed] ;set traveling Speed
M117 Printing... ;Put printing message on LCD screen
Simplify3D End Script

This script is to help my part cooling faster

M104 S0 ; turn off extruder
M140 S0 ; turn off bed
M104 S0
M140 S0
;Retract the filament
G92 E1
G1 E-3 F300
G28 X0 Y0

G91 ; relative movements
G1 F150 ; slow Z rate
G1 Z15 ; Z up 15mm
G90 ; back to absolute

G28 X0 ; home X axis
G28 Y0 ; home Y axis
G0 X110 Y150 F800 ; move head to middle

M106 S255 ; turn fan on high

G4 P60000 ;whait one minute
G4 P60000 ;whait one minute
G4 P60000 ;whait one minute
G4 P60000 ;whait one minute
G4 P60000 ;whait one minute

M106 S0 ; turn fan off
G1 X0 Y200 F1000 ; prepare for part removal
M84 ; disable motors

For Mini PCs that are compatible with VESA 100 x 100 mounts, these two brackets (one left, one right) will allow the computer to be mounted beneath a desk or table. Requires four M4 machine screws for attaching the brackets to the computer, and six pan- or truss-head wood screws for attaching the bracket/computer combo to the desk.

Originally designed for the HP EliteDesk 800 G1.

Attach the brackets to the PC first, using M4 machine screws and with the flat side of the brackets pointed away from the PC. Leave the points of the brackets to the back and sides of the PC, so the front of the PC can sit flush with the table edge.

Once brackets are secured to the PC, attach using wood screws (#10 or #12) to the underside of desk or table, leaving at least an inch of clearance from the desk's edge to avoid splitting/weakening the tabletop.

Completed mount, shown from below. The PC's face can sit flush with the table edge.

This was designed in SketchUp, starting with a 100mm x 100mm square, with a circle at each corner that was slightly larger than the diameter of an M4 screw post. The original design ended up being larger than my printable area, so I split it in half.

The "Just For Fun" foosball table is a pretty nice toy-quality table that stands up to adults playing on it, but the weakest link is the handles. The inside of the handle should be cylindrical, but instead they used 4 thin fins (pictured) to save material. They feel flimsy, and one of them even broke and could not be used. So I created this replacement, which is much stronger, and I will eventually replace all the handles.

description.text:
I wont have time to print the model and assemble/test it for a while, especially since it's winter here, but all of the files are done and should be print ready. Will update when I get that far.

The model has raised gills and eyes, and a hole to fill with paint to act as a gill spot (roughly the same location as it is on the real thing it's based off of),

I decided to go with 2 designs, the "Standard" design - "O1" - that Sthone used with his crankbait model (https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1729443), and the method that I see on production brands, where the hook anchor points are short and wrapped around material - "O2" - instead of threading a wire throughout the whole body of the lure.

I know that Sthone's method works well and is strong, so the manufaturing method is an experiment and also allows for bigger chambers and more shot to be put inside of it.

O2 has holes inside of the hook anchor points that are meant for 1.75mm filament to be put inside to help with lining the two halves up.

Any tips would also be appreciate, let me know if there are any problems.

Printer:

Anet A8

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

.1

Infill:

~20%

Notes:

Lipless crankbaits are designed to sink, so unless you want it to float mind the infill. Enough weight added to it when it's done should cause it to sink, but less infill will mess with that.

You don't need supports to print, but because the chambers are so big, I decided to add my own supports into the model that have to be taken out after it's done. If your printer can handle an overhang that large then they aren't needed, but it's an option just in case.

Everything I know about post production with fishing lures I learned from Sthone. You can find everything you need to know about it from his design, here: https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1729443

This lure can be assembled the same as way as Sthone's lure.

I use .040 Stainless Steel Lure Wire from Lurepartsonline.com
All modeling was done in Solidworks and done from scratch based off of measurements taken from an actual lipless crankbait, and then modified from that general size.
I made Sthone's lure, and wanted to make a lipless crankbait using that same style. I found that the lipless crankbait options online were a notch above nonexistent, so I designed my own.

description.text: This was printed on a Robo 3D R1+ with a .6mm nozzle. The tolerances on mine were a little off, but with a hammer I was able to lightly pound it into place. I did design the back to have a little bit of flex to adjust for a tight fit. The backplate IS recommended, as it adds a certain level of rigidity. The screw holes were designed with a roughly 30 degree down-angle so that downward pull will distribute the weight evenly between the backplate and the screws. Smaller nozzles will take longer to print this, but I tried to keep it simple and optimize the design for quick and simple printing. This was printed in about 20-30 minutes on my robo with the .6mm nozzle, I would imagine a .4mm or .2mm would take significantly longer. Filament used was worksteel wood filament. Remixes are welcomed but please note the non-commercial share alike licensing. Enjoy!

I need a cheap universal joint for a project I am working on so I have been playing with a few options. This is the one that seems the best so far. It is using a plastic ball from a wall track toy which is pretty far from a perfect sphere but it seems to work very well anyway. For the project I will use a cheap 1/2" steel bearing and laser cut the pieces from Delrin which has low friction. I will probably use nylock nuts on the screws to be able to adjust how stiff the movement is. Video of it here http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=uxKQXoyVtPg
The bearing in these drawings is .722 in (18.34mm) so you will need to scale the holes to suit whatever size bearing you use.

author: asantosjr

description.text: Its a toilet seat hinge what else can I say hope it helps someone else out.

This is my implementation of a white board string-plotter.
The mechanical parts are designed to use inexpensive 28BYJ-48 5V stepper motors (search for them on Amazon - they sell for ~$6, including driver). More details under 'Instructions'.
UPDATE: I added links to the sources of some of the software I wrote for this project under 'Instructions'.

All parts are modules inside the provided .scad file - the code is not exactly pretty, but should be usable.
The pen guide on the carriage in the original design was to short, so I printed an extension (just cylindrical pipes, really) and super-glued them to the existing carriage (they don't have to take any real mechanical load). The guide is sized to hold an 'Expo' brand dry erase marker.
There is a small 9g servo on the bottom of the carriage that allows the pen to be retracted, so that the plotter can move without drawing a line.
After experimenting with various types of fishing line I settled on using dental floss as string and two pieces of knitting yarn to hold the carriage such that it can easily roatate.
For electronics I am using a Teensy 3.0 microcontroller board (ARM-based, but mostly Arduino compatible - a regular Arduino would work just fine, too) and a HC-05 (check Amazon) bluetooth module as a serial pipe (yes, the plotter is wireless).
On the software side, I have implemnted two solutions:
  • A Perl script that takes cartesian moves as inputs and generates spool-rotation steps as output that get sent to the plotter directly via bluetooth
  • An Android app that allows you to doodle on the touch screen of your phone and then send the results to the plotter directly (again via bluetooth)
    I also created auxiliary scripts to render photographs (any jpg, really) as line drawings by turning them into grayscale images and generating a square-wave path whose frequency is modulated by the 'darkness' of the image area (see the two images attached).
    The device is rather slow, its speed is limited by how fast the stepper motors can turn without missing steps. Realistically, plotting the more complex photo in this post (w/ two faces) took about 1.5 hours.
    EDIT: For completeness' sake, here is the script that controls the plotter:
    https://www.dropbox.com/s/ug2ghe095nh04gd/wb_plotter.pl
    And this is the script used to generate the photo plots:
    https://www.dropbox.com/s/6fvj2abrmj4mfep/pixelverter.pl
    This is the Arduino (Teensy) sketch that controls the electronics:
    https://www.dropbox.com/s/4qqyd2zk95t5r01/EtchASketch.ino

comments.text:
I've been watching this Thing for a while and was hoping for more traction. I want to build one but have the following concerns: I haven't looked at the scad file yet, but I don't see a model for all the parts I expect. I don't see models / STLs for the pen clips or any type of axle for the steppers etc. The bottom line is that I really would like to see pictures of the actual "thing", not just its output (the whiteboard image). A video of it in action would be inspiring as well.
I don't see any assembly diagrams or instructions, and it is unclear what motors need to be purchased. You mention the model number of a stepper on the description page, and a 9g servo in the instructions. How many steppers are used? I would think at least 2. Is it weighted? Sprung? Is it a delta configuration? I really can't tell.
I like what you've done with the Perl scripts. Very clever. Using a Teensy and BlueTooth are also super cool. I'm really excited to learn more. Thanks!
comments.author: SPGilmore

title: Mini Mil X axis CNC conversion

description.text:
These are the parts needed to convert a mini mill (specifically: harbor freight. Verify dimensions and interfaces with your other-branded mini mill prior to printing) to CNC using NEMA 23 steppers. Print with ABS at 100% infill. You might be tempted to print the oldham coupler vertically but don't do it, the z layers are the weakest interface and they will fail in torque more readily than one printed along the X or Y axes.

The plate is a substitute for the existing (plastic) plate. Only downside of this is, it makes chips harder to clean out (since the original plastic plate isn't structural you can leave the screws a bit loose and just pop the plate up/down and brush out chips). However I deemed this advantageous as I wanted the handwheel on the other side and bumping it out 6" or so (using a dual shaft stepper) was unattractive at best.

You need two M6x20 bolts for bolting to the mill, four M5x20 for bolting to the motor (with lock nuts) and some m3 bolts for the oldham coupling.

Unloaded this works fine. Under load the coupling on the motor side slips against the motor shaft. This part needs to be made out of aluminum - pretty straightforward if you have the mill in functioning shape. I am fairly confident the other two parts of the coupler can remain printed (at least long enough to get full CNC capability, then make some sweet CNC parts)

video: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=7KXM-7N3lYo

I have a blog where I am documenting the conversion of my mini mill in near-real-time: http://harborfreightcnc.blogspot.com

title: Camry Caddy
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - No Derivatives

description.text:
I made this because every time my wife and I go somewhere in her car we need somewhere to put our mods and my phone without them flopping around. I designed this to be bottomless and it fits perfectly in the squarish void in the center console. I know it will fit in a 2011 Camry. description.text:
Archaeologists found this game in the tomb of an official named Reniseneb. The game of Hounds and Jackals was important to Egyptians who lived during the Middle Kingdom (approximately 4,000 years ago). We know this because they have found many examples of these game boards at Middle Kingdom archaeological sites.
This game is probably played liked today's Chutes and Ladders. The course probably started in the middle of the board. The two players would race each other, moving their pieces down and around the outer edge and up to the hole at the very top.
You have a Board (Lid) and Box to hold the pieces you only need a dice to finish this set.

A simple puzzle based on the hexagonal tortoise problem.

The hexagonal tortoise problem was proposed by a Korean mathematician some 300 years ago. The N vertices of a hexagonal array are given numbers from 1 to N. The numbers are arranged so that the sum of the six integers at the vertices of each hexagon is the same. The original "magic" tortoise pattern, which contains 9 hexagons, was published in 1700. The sums of the integers at the vertices of each hexagon are 93. See - https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hexagonal_tortoise_problem

Tortoise.stl is a copy of this pattern; it can be used to check the sums. Note that the central hexagon is consecutively numbered; a clue to its construction ?

A solution to the 8 hexagon problem is apparent in tortoise.stl. Remove vertices number 1,29 and 30. Adjust the integers on the remaining 27 vertices so that they range from 1 to 27. The sums of the integers at hexagon vertices will be 87.

The puzzle, hex_puzzle.stl, is composed of three hexagons with vertices numbered from 1 through 13. Solutions occur where the sums of the integers at the vertices of each of the hexagons range from 34 through 50. A solution for the sum 43 is printed on the puzzle.

Tokens labeled from 1 through 13 are provided. The problem is to place the tokens in the puzzle finding solutions other than 43, particularly 34 and 50.

OpenSCAD code is included.

Printer Brand:

MakerBot

Printer:

MakerBot Replicator (5th Generation)

Rafts:

Yes

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.2 mm

Looking at the puzzle one sees that the three hexagons share a single vertex. Three other vertices are shared by the three possible pairs of hexagons. This suggests a starting place for solutions for the minimum and maximum sums, 34 and 50. For the minimum sum, 34, the value at the single unique vertex is likely 1, and the values at the shared vertices probably 2, 3, and 4. For the maximum sum, 50, the value at the single unique vertex is probably 13, and the values at the shared vertices 10, 11, and 12. The nine leftover pieces need to be separated into three groups of three to complete the desired sums. Answers for other sums can be found with a similar technique.

author: telepathboy

description.text:
Inspired by a certain green one eyed animated movie character, here we have Mike Drozowski.
At just 92mm between motors and designed for only 1S batteries it is really only a novelty for LOS flying. That said the frame is actually very sturdy due to its hollow arm design and is well suited to an FPV setup for these 0703 or 0705 motors.

The parts list is quite simple:

  • TinyFISH FC
  • TinyPEPPER 4in1 ESC
  • 4x BR0703 15000KV motors
  • 300mAh 1s battery
  • A set of 60mm QX90 propellers (green to keep with the theme but any will work)
  • 2 pin JST PH2.0 socket & wire for a battery connector
  • 4x M2x12 nylon screws
  • 25mm googly eye

If you purchase the Banggood Racestar rip off of the fishPEPPER electronics then they will be supplied with the necessary mounting fasteners. Do note however that their version of the flight controller is an old revision of the TinyFISH design and may have reliability issues when a battery is fully charged. It will still basically work and can be corrected but for a list of more reputable sources that supply the latest revision of the design check the fishPEPPER project pages.

Resolution:

0.2mm

Notes:

I have printed the components in ABS however I'm sure that most any rigid filament will work just fine.
I use an extrusion width of 0.5mm with a 0.4mm nozzle. As such wall thicknesses are typically a multiple of 0.5mm.

The frame must be printed with supports turned off so that the arms remain hollow for the motor wires to pass through.

The head must be printed with supports for the eye hole but will not require supports elsewhere. Be sure the screw holes aren't filled with support material.
Don't go to crazy with infill on the head as it is all excess weight, keep it as low as your printer will allow whilst maintaining a good print quality.

Depending on how well bridging has worked for you the arms may need to be cleared to allow the motor wires to pass easily. A small piece of plastic tube such as an antennae tube pushed in and out will free up any loose strands of plastic.

All holes will need to be drilled out to suit their fasteners:

  • Drill 1.6mm motor mounting holes on the frame (or wiggle a 1.5mm drill bit around).
  • Drill 2mm ESC and FC mounting holes on the frame.
  • Drill 1.5mm holes in to the bottom of the head and tap an M2 thread in each. If you don't have an M2 tap then screwing a metal M2 fastener in to the hole should do the trick.

Cleanup and deburr all edges as desired.

Glue the eye in place with super glue (CA glue).

The M2 screws are installed from the bottom and thread in to the head to hold the electronics stack together.

title: Hal 9000 case for Yi Home/HD Camera (possibly Nest Cameras)

description.text:
Contribute: https://github.com/heyharvs/hal9000

"I want to use the boring stand that my Yi Home camera came with...." - me
"I'm sorry Dave, I'm afraid I can't let you do that." - camera

This is a nifty wall mount that replaces the stock camera mount for the popular Yi Home camera and possibly the HD and Nest.

Link to Camera: https://goo.gl/KftwjR

It prints as 3 pieces: a gray speaker grill, a gray frame, and a black insert with the camera mount. The tolerances are pretty close so expect some very light sanding to pop in the pieces correct. It comes with a screw mount at the top and requires no glue or screws to assemble. It's designed to print on a 200mm printer.

Speaker: I left the speaker grill as a separate piece so you can paint it if you want it slightly off color. Because of the high level of detail, it's quite a test for a printer, but the imperfections work in its favor

Black Insert: The insert is 4mm in height. To get the gray trim around the logo and camera, pause and do a filament change at 4.1mm+ or configure your slicer to pause the print. Of course you can always just paint it, but I think this looks better.

Stickers: I included 2 stickers that you can print and stick on with a gluestick.

Ignore the version numbers in the filenames. Those are my revisions where I was testing with nubs and other clips to snap the pieces in place.

Enjoy!!

Turbidity is a description of how cloudy water is. It's opposite would be clarity. The cloudiness can be caused from organic (phytoplankton) or inorganic (silt) material suspended in the water. Turbidity is an important indicator of water quality. The suspended particles can increase water temperatures, interfere with photosynthesis, clog gills, provide a place for harmful microorganisms to proliferate and help suspend some toxic substances in the water column. These days turbidity is often measured with a digital instrument that quantifies how much a beam (or two) of light is scattered by particles suspended in the water. These instruments will give you a number in Nephelometric Turbidity Units (NTU's). A simpler method is to lower a secchi disk (a circle divided into opposing white and black quadrants) into a body of water until it is no longer visible. This distance is then measured for comparison with other locations. A secchi disk can also be incorporated into a clear tube and a water sample slowly released from the tube until the disk becomes visible. The depth of water left in the tube is then measured for comparison with other locations. These turbidity tubes are useful when you want to sample turbidity from shore. Turbidity tubes are a great way for students to explore what turbidity is. Good quality turbidity tubes can be a bit expensive though. So why not make some.... This Thing is a small portable version of a turbidity tube (though you can make yours as big as you like). You need to paint two opposing quadrants white on the inside of the base to make your secchi disk. To convert your readings to NTU's use the chart found at: http://extension.usu.edu/utahwaterwatch/monitoring/field-instructions/turbidity/turbiditytube/turbiditytubeconversionchart Materials:
  • 3D printed parts (I printed mine at 0.4mm as fast as my Afinia H480 would go and the parts fit perfectly inside the clear tube).
  • Clear Fluorescent tube cover (available in most hardware stores)
  • Silicone
  • Permanent marker
  • White waterproof paint
    • To build you will need to follow these steps:
  • Print the parts
  • Cut the tube to desired length (I use 30 or 60 centimeters).
  • Paint two opposing quadrants on the inside of the base white.
  • Connect everything (perhaps use a bit of silicone when attaching the base to prevent leaks)
  • Add graduations (either by hand or with a sticker). This website has a nice selection of rulers you can print and attached to your tube. https://printable-ruler.net/all-rulers/
    • To use:
  • Place finger or thumb over hole in base
  • Dip tube into aquatic system to be surveyed, fill to top
  • Hold vertical and look through tube from top to bottom
  • Remove your finger or thumb from hole and slowly let water out until you can see secchi disk at bottom.
  • Recover hole.
  • Measure how much water is left in tube.

If your a teacher and want to use these with a class consider comparing the turbidity of two or three nearby water bodies and have the students attempt to explain any differences based on their observations of each system.  Observing changes through the fall or spring are also fun and interesting for students to chart and explain.
This is a remixed item (added a hole) so it could be used on this ghost: https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1101793

title: REI Kingdom Table Center Support Pieces

description.text:
I bought an REI Kingdom table at the REI garage sale for $20. The table came with 4 cross-members for the ends. It should have come with 2 cross-members for the ends and 2 center cross-members with locating pins. I took some pictures of the correct pieces in the store on another table and designed replacement locating pins in Tinkercad for the center cross-members. I then modified two of the extra end cross-members by cutting off the end tabs, drilling holes for my part, and riveting them on to make them into the correct center cross-members. It works perfectly. Good as new and saved $80.
I recommend printing at over 50% infill in ABS. If you know how to mix density printing I would suggest printing at 100% for the entire locating pin.

Ford uses this filter size on pretty much all vehicles with 1.00 1.60 2.00 & 2.50 liter engines. Also pretty common in Chrysler vehicles and most other brands use it some as well. Also, It is possible the socket may fit some other filter brands that are the equivalent size but don't know either way. Some will probably have a different # of facets. This has 15.

Fits a 3/8" socket.

I provided two versions. A tight fit and a looser fit which is .5mm wider in diameter around the filter. The one I made myself is the "tighter fit". It was able to push it on, but had to rap it fairly hard to get it back off. I fixed that by heating it a bit with a heat gun and then pressed on a filter. After that it fit perfectly. I have not tested the looser fit but it should work.

title: Hypercube Two Z-axis - MKS SBASE V1.3
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text: This design of the great development of the hypercube evolution XYcore published by SCOTT_3D and Tech2C presents a version with 2020 extrusions used for the frame and the platform frame, bowden extruder and a MKS SBASE v1.3 board for the control system.

FIRST: Draw an approach

I decided to draw the hypercube evolution parts to fit with 2020 extrusions and work with a bowden extruder using Sketchup.

SECOND: Bill Of Materials (BOM)

After I have my desing ready in Sketchup I decided to create an excel file ( See file BOM_HYPERCUBE171029.xlsx) with all the components and links where to buy them.

FRAME AND LINEAR GUIDES

  • One Set HyperCube 3D 2020 Link
  • 2020 aluminum extrusion profile 500mm Link
  • 20pcs/lot T Slot L Shape Type 90 2020 Link
  • 20 x 28 L connector bracket use 2020 aluminum profiles Link
  • 8mm diameter X rails Link
  • 10mm diameter Y rails Link
  • 12mm diameter Z rails Link

FASTERNERS

  • M5 x 10 Button head screws ISO7380 Perno A2-70 Link
  • M3 Socket head screws Link
  • M5 T Nut Hammer Nut Aluminum Connector T for 2020 Link
  • MTGATHER 100pcs/lot M5 Hammer Nut Aluminum Connector T Fastener Link

PULLEYS AND BELTS

  • GT2 Timing Pulley (20 teeth) 5mm bore for 6mm belt Link
  • GT2 Idler Pulley (20 teeth) 3mm bore Link
  • GT2 Idler Pulley without teeth (20 teeth) 3mm bore Link
  • 5m Polyurethane GT2 6mm belt Link
  • Screw Copper Nuts Spring Kit Link
  • Screw Copper Nuts Spring Kit Link

LINEAR_BEARINGS

  • LM12UU 12mm Linear Ball Bearings Link
  • LM10UU 10mm Linear Ball Bearings Link
  • LM8UU 8mm Linear Ball Bearings Link

HEATED BED AND COMPONENTS

  • Heated Bed 214X214mm Link
  • 4 or 6 x Levelling screws Link
  • 1 x 100kohm NTC3950 thermistor Link
  • 2 x Optical Endstop End Stop Limit Switch Solution Link
  • 3D Printer Fan 5015 12V 24V 0.15A Sleeve Bearing Brushless Fan  Link
  • NJK-5002D Magnetic induction Proximity Switch hall sensor switch M12 DC5-24V 3 wires NPN NC 8mm distance Link

STEPPER MOTORS

  • 3 x NEMA 17 42mm Stepper Motors Link
  • 2 x NEMA 17 Lead Screw M8 Link

EXTRUDER & HOTEND

  • E3D TITAN/ultimaker Link
  • v6 J-head Hotend with Fan and tube + Volcano kit Link

CONTROLLER BOARD

  • Controller board MKS SBASE V1.3 Link
  • 3d printing touch screen RepRap controller panel MKS TFT28 V2.0 Link
  • MKS TFT-WIFI V1.0 APP 3D printing wireless router ESP8266 WIFI module Link

comments.author: jjarur

comments.text:
You can not connect the two motors in parallel to a single driver because the total current used is more than 3 A (Two 17 NEMA 1.5 A). I use a single driver for each motor (MKS BASE has 5 drivers) enslaving one driver to another and connecting the control pins for both drivers together. In my case I wanted the driver 5 to be the slave to the driver 3, so I connected
EN3 to EN5
ST3 to ST5
DIR3 to DIR5
(Watch the attached picture)
Take a look at the following video for more information:
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=b0dCM0JDYOM

This has 3 miniature signs that are printed on boards. They have a Halloween type theme of monsters or warnings. The signs consist of a post with holes and two pegs along with a base. A sign board that is blank is also provided so you can paint your own words and attach to the bases. The bases have stone designs with a wood support beam. Note that the hole in the bases for the pegs will have to be cleaned out. The signs have holes also that are the same size as the pegs that need to be glued to the signs. Note these holes may need to be cleaned out as well before super glueing.
The signs can be set up to be snapped into the bases or you can just superglue them permenantly to the base sign post.

title: BIF RC Lantian X3 Upgrade Kit

description.text:
Being the micro quad lover I am, I recently purchased the parts to build a Lantian X3. I believe that the "X3" refers to the 3" prop size it can support. I've owned a few 5" builds and quite a few 2" builds, but never a 3" build. Long story short, I instantly fell in love with it and, of course, heavily modded it.

Note that the X3 build was VERY tight. Don't plan to get any more than 3 layers onto your flight stack. Even with only 3 layers, I had to trim down the nylon spacers quite a bit. You may want to look into getting single ESCs instead of a 4 in 1 plate.

TPU Camera Mount
The stock PLA camera mount the frame shipped with wasn't printed with 100% infill or nearly enough shells, causing it to split in half immediately after I tried to install it. I just replicated the design and printed it in TPU in hopes to help reduce video vibrations.

TPU ATX03/VTX03 Mount
I decided to use the VTX03 video transmitter because it's light, cheap, and is selectable from 0-200mw. It also comes with a whip antenna which is much more durrable than the common clover leaf antennas. As for the mount, it should fit the ATX03 (has audio), VTX03, and other similar VTXs. It's simply a TPU slot that slides onto one of the upper hex spacers on the frame and grabs the top of the VTX. Make sure to install a small piece of foam between your camera and VTX to avoid shorting due to the tight tolerances!

1106 TPU Motor Guards
To assist in vibration isolation and motor protection, I designed some motor guards specialized for 1106 motors and to be printed in TPU. For more ways to protect your 11XX motors, check out my 11XX Motor Guard Post

11XX TPU Motor Soft Mount Pads
For the first time, I tried soft mounting my motors. It's totally worth it! My quads flies silky smooth! Make sure to use these with the TPU motor guards as it isolates the vibrations from the screws from both sides.

Current hardware:

Disclaimer: some of these are affiliate links, but all of the links are to the best place to buy each item. That's why not all links are affiliate links. If you do purchase these parts, I kindly ask that you use my links as that's where I get funding to create more open source mods like these. Thanks!

This hardware will create a 3S monster capable of cruising at 60mph and able to turn on a dime!

Lantian Parts
-Lantian X3 2.5mm carbon fiber frame
-HGLRC 20x20mm F4 flight controller stack, 25A ESC, OSD, BEC, black box
-Brother Hobby returner R3 1106 5100kv motor
-Minicube 20x20mm receiver and buzzer
-Eachine ATX03 VTX (with audio)
-TWC25 700tvl micro FPV camera
-Gemfan 3035 polycarbonate propellers
-550mah 3s 70c LiPo (this will give you a serious punch)
-550mah 2s 80c LiPo (this will still give you plenty of power, but will be easier to fly for beginner pilots)

Other Gear
-Fatshark dominator HD3 modular FPV headset
-Realacc RX5808 pro plus diversity receiver
-Taranis QX7 Frsky transmitter
-Triple feed patch antenna
-Pagoda 2 antenna

Battery Charging
-IMAX B6AC V2 professional balance charger
-Parallel charging board (this will allow you to charge 6 batteries at once!)
-Fireproof LiPo charging bag

Connectors and Silicone Wire
-16 gauge silicone wire (to wire your battery to your ESC plate)
-XT30 connectors (to wire your battery to your ESC plate)
-XT60-XT30 connector adapters (you'll need these to connect your batteries to the parallel charging board)

Just a word of advice, buy a crap ton of propellers and batteries. It really sucks to be out of the air for a month because of a stupid propeller. Having a ton of batteries is also great because you can spend more time flying and less time charging! Buy at least 5.

eBay Link
Don't own a 3D printer? No problem! Purchase the Lantian X3 upgrade kit on eBay.
If you're just looking to purchase the Ninjaflex TPU soft mount pads, you can get them too on eBay.

Onshape

I designed it all in Onshape. If you're looking for an easy way to create a remix, don't hesitate to create a copy of my public document.
